ying to say that one is better than the other..saying that me personally, I=

 reel to reel...mostly cuz I dont have the paitence and I am hooked on that=
 real time(almost real time) comms I get with the hack...but it would be co=
ol (for me)to be able to try out some of those older methods but Im sure(fo=
r me) that Id go back to my hack...just my opinion on something and not say=
ing its right or wrong or one method is better than another.=A0 I'll shut u=
p now and go back to bed..have a great day

d if you can afford it
and have the paitence to try that method...go for it=

I do both with investigations a=
nd such, bring along analog and digital
recorders (and being a musician I s=
till work with both technologies as
well). There's certain tonal and depth =
qualities that get sampled out
in digital as well as different types of art=
ifacting that digital
produces, just as there's certain clarities not capab=
le in analog with
out a lot of extra work besides the ease of use of the me=
dium.

Marty

ot? For myself, I

to go through
so much recorded 
> material for so little in return, content=
 wise, when we already have
the ability (albeit in it's 
> infancy) to enga=
ge in real-time, or nearly real-time, two-way
conversations.

> Yes, Sara=
h got amazing results and bless her pioneering spirit which
helped bring us=
 to 
> where we are today. I'm not sure how much of her success was her
equ=
ipment and how

r
sessions). In regard to 
> traditional EVP work, given how good many of t=
oday's inexpensive
digital recorders are, 
> that is the route I've gone fo=
r situations where sweep isn't an
option. I've gotten good EVP 
> with my P=
anasonic RR-US360, the Sony B26, and a handful of others. I
know some are 
=
> still successfully using cassettes. 
> 
> I guess it all boils down to a =
matter of preference and the type of
EVP research that most 
> interests yo=
u. As my dear hubby says, "Whatever floats your boat!" ;-)
>

ecide to try Sarah's method, let us know how you do.
